entries.fullText:
Something Left Undone,

BY LONGFELLOW.

Labor with what zeal we will,
Something still remains undone!
Something uncompleted still,
Waits the rising of the sun.

By the bedside, on the stair,
At the threshold, near the gates,
With its menace or its prayer,
Like a medicant it waits:

Waits, and will not go away-
Waits, and will not be gainsaid
By the cares of yesterday,
Each to-day is heavier made.

Till at length it is, or seems,
Greater than our strength can bear,
As the burden of our dreams,
Pressing on us everywhere!

And we stand from day to day,
Like the dwarfs of times gone by,
Who, as Northern legends say,
On their shoulders held the sky.
entries.summaryText: The journal entry contains a poem titled 'Something Left Undone' by Longfellow.

DIARY

WILLY WALLACH,

entries.fullText:
The Chicago Journal says that Wendell Phillips'
return of property amounts to $702,000, for
nearly a million of money, and that of Charles
Francis Adams, United States Minister to England,
to $328,800.
entries.summaryText: Journal entry with financial information from an unknown date.

Loyal men, whether

Ottumwa Kansas
out of 150 voters, 23
were sacrificed in the
war from 61 to 65

entries.fullText:
FIRST.
A PARTIAL ECLIPSE OF THE MOON, night of April 10-11.
Visible as follows:
NEW YORK:
Moon Enters Penumbra : 10d. 9h. 6m. A.
Moon Enters Shadow..... : 10d. 10h. 49m. A.
Middle of Eclipse...............: 10d. 11h. 42m. A.
Moon leaves Shadow..... : 11d. 0h. 35m. M.
Moon Leaves Penumbra : 11d. 2h. 17m. M.
ST. LOUIS:
Moon Enters Penumbra : 10d. 8h. 1m. A.
Moon Enters Shadow..... : 10d. 9h. 44m. A.
Middle of Eclipse................ : 10d. 10h. 37m. A.
Moon leaves Shadow..... : 10d. 11h. 30m A.
Moon Leaves Penumbra : 11d. 1h. 12m. M.
SAN FRANCISCO:
Moon Enters Penumbra : 10d. 5h. 52m. A.
Moon Enters Shadow..... : 10d. 7h. 35m. A.
Middle of Eclipse................ : 10d. 8h. 28m. A.
Moon leaves Shadow..... : 10d. 9h. 21m. A.
Moon Leaves Penumbra : 10d. 11h. 3m. A.
entries.summaryText: A partial eclipse of the moon on April 10-11 visible in New York, St. Louis, and San Francisco.

entries.fullText:
SECOND
A TOTAL ECLIPSE OF THE SUN, April 25.--Visible to South
America and Africa.
entries.summaryText: A total eclipse of the sun on April 25 visible in South America and Africa.

entries.fullText:
THIRD
A PARTIAL ECLIPSE OF THE MOON, evening of October 4.
Visible to Europe, Asia, and Africa: partially visible
to the United States.
NEW YORK:
Moon leaves Shadow..... : 4d. 6h. 45m. A.
Moon Leaves Penumbra : 4d. 7h. 58m. A.
ST. LOUIS:
Moon leaves Shadow..... : 0d. 0h. 0m.
Moon Leaves Penumbra : 4d. 6h. 53m. A.
SAN FRANCISCO:
Invisible
entries.summaryText: A partial eclipse of the moon on October 4 visible to Europe, Asia, and Africa and partially visible to the United States.

entries.fullText:
FOURTH
AN ANNULAR ECLIPSE OF THE SUN, October 19.-- Visible to
North America and Parts of Europe, Africa, and
South America.
New York:
Eclipse begins : 19d. 9h. 2m. M.
Eclipse ends.... : 19d. 0h. 12m. A.
St. Louis:
Eclipse begins : 19d. 7h. 47m. M.
Eclipse ends.... : 19d. 10h. 42m. M.
San Francisco:
Eclipse begins : Sunrise
Eclipse ends.... : 19d. 8h. 1m. M.
entries.summaryText: An annular eclipse of the sun on October 19 visible in North America and parts of Europe, Africa, and South America.

MOON'S PHASES. MOON'S PHASES,

A TABLE OF
STAMP DUTIES,
As Amended March 3, 1863.
AGREEMENT, CONTRACT, or APPRAISEMENT, not otherwise
specified, each sheet 5
BANK CHECK, DRAFT, or ORDER FOR MONEY, payable
at sight or on demand, over $20 2
BILL OF SALE OF VESSEL, consideration not over $500 25
Over $2500 and not over $1000 50
For every additional $1,000, or part thereof, 50 cents
more.
BILL OF LADING, or Receipt for any goods for foreign export,
(Except to British North America,) 10
BOND for the performance of the duties of office, or of indemnity
for the payment of money 50
BONDS, other than in legal proceedings, if not otherwise
provided for 25
CERTIFICATE OF STOCK, in incorporated company 25
CERTIFICATE OF PROFITS, in incorporated company, if
for $10, and not over $50 10
Exceeding $50 25
CERTIFICATE OF DAMAGE, and all Certificates issued by
any port warden or marine surveyor 25
CERTIFICATE OF DEPOSIT, $100 or less 2
Over $100 5
(certificates of measurement of weights or animals, wood,
coal, or other articles, Certificate of Record of Deed, or
acknowledgement thereof, by attesting witness, require no stamp.)
CERTIFICATE, of any other description 5
CHARTER PARTY, of vessel or steamer not over 150 tons 1 00
Over 150 toms and not over 500 3 00
Over 300 tons and not over 600 5 00
Over 600 tons 10 00
entries.summaryText: Stamp duties table.

entries.fullText:
TELEGRAPHIC DISPATCH, when charge for first ten words
is 20 cents or less . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1
When over 20 cents. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 3
WAREHOUSE RECEIPT, for property stored. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 25
WITHDRAWAL from bonded warehouse. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 50
WRITS, or other original process, for beginings suits, (except
before a Justice of the Pace, or commenced by
the United States or any State,). . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 50


PROPRIETARY, Medicines, Perfumery, &c., each package retailed
at not over 25 cents, 1 cent; over 25 and not over 50
cents, 2 cents; over 50 and not over 75 cents, 3 cents; over 75
cents and not over $1.00, 4 cents. Every additional 50 cents, or
part thereof, 3 cents more.

PLAYING CARDS, price not over 18 cents each pack, 1 cent;
over 18 and not over 25 cents, 2 cents; over 25 and not over 30
cents, 3 cents; over 30 and not over 36 cents, 4 cents; over 36
cents, 5 cents.
-----
The indiscriminate use of all kinds of stamps (except
postage of proprietary) is permitted, care being taken to affix a
stamp or stamps of the proper amount.
-----
Documents made in any foreign country, to be used in the
United States, shall pay the same duty as when made here. The
party to whom the same is issued, or by whom it is used, shall
affix thereon the proper stamp, before using.
No deed, or mortgage of real estate. shall be require to pay a
stamp duty of over $1,000 in any event.

Powers of Attorney, or other papers relating to applications
for bounties, arrearages of pay, or pensions, require no stamp;
neither do warrants of attorney accompanying a bond or note
when such bond or note shall be stamped; and whenever any
bond or note shall be secured by mortgage, but one stamp duty
is required, provided the stamp duty placed thereon is the highest
rate required for said instrument, or either of them.
No document signed or issued prior to June 1st, 1863, without
being stamped, shall be invalid for that reason; but it shall not
be admitted or used in any court until it shall have been stamped,
and the initials of the person using, and the date when it is
used, placed thereon.
entries.summaryText: This entry contains information about stamp duties and the use of stamps for various documents and items.
This entry contains a table of stamp duties for various types of notes and bills of exchange.

entries.fullText:
RATES OF POSTAGE.
Letters to any part of the Untied States, 3 cents for each 1-2 ounce or part thereof.
Drop Letters, 2 cents.
Advertised Letters, 1 cent, in addition to the regular rates.
Valuable Letters may be registered on application at the office of mailing, and the payment of a registration fee not exceeding 20 cents.
Transient Newspapers, Periodicals, Pamphlets, Blanks, Proof Sheets, Book Manuscripts, and all mailable printed matter, (except circulars and books,) 2 cents for each and every 4 ounces. Double these rates are charged for Books.
Unsealed Circulars, (to one address) not exceeding 3 in number, 2 cents, and in the same proportion for a greater number.
Seeds, Cuttings, Roots, &c., 2 cents for each 4 ounces or less quantity.
All Packages of Mail Matter not charged with letter postage must be so arranged that the same can be conveniently examined by Postmasters; if not, letter postage will be charged.
No Package will be forwarded by mail which weighs over 4 pounds.
All Postage Matter, for delivery within the United States, must be prepaid by stamps (except duly certified letters of soldiers and sailors); otherwise, double the above rates will be charged on delivery.
Weekly Newspapers (one copy only) sent to actual Subscribers within the County where printed and published, free.
Letters to Canada and other British North American Provinces, when not over 3000 miles, 10 cents for each 1-2 ounce. When over 3000 miles, 15 cents. Prepayment optional.
Letters to Great Britain or Ireland, 24 cents. Prepayment optional.
Letters to France, 15 cents for each 1-4 ounce. Prepayment optional.
Letters to other Foreign Countries vary in rate according to the route by which they are sent, and the proper information can be obtained of any Postmaster in the United States.
entries.summaryText: Rates of postage.

entries.fullText:
4 [?] Place. Our
Bleecher - near [Thomface?]
entries.summaryText: Location mentioned.

entries.fullText:
raised 73.000 bales of Cotton
in 1850 - at $500 per bale
amounts to $36.300,000 -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the amount of cotton raised in Carroll Parish Louisiana in 1850.
Susan B. Anthony did not write an entry on this day.

entries.fullText:
Cleveland to Toledo 112 miles
Toledo to Chicago 248
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Cleveland to Toledo and then to Chicago.
No entry written on this day.

entries.fullText:
Chicago - Melissa &
Cousin H. Anthony went to
Collier's (Robert) Church - a
splendid Church - "And
Herod feared John" -
saw J. P. Fogg - spoke with
Mr. C. - called on H. Dick-
son (Boyles) - (Charles) -
then on Mrs Loomis
saw Emma Griffing - P.O.
Box 1192 - walked back
found Brother D.R. had
been there - en route for
Washington - he took airs
at 5-, _ There is a skele
ton in Aunt A. E's home
Rum D fear - it is a terribly
sad revelation
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Collier's Church and meets with various people in Chicago, including Emma Griffing and Brother D.R., before discovering a sad revelation at Aunt A. E's home.

entries.fullText:
Took cars for Quincy at
12 Sunday night _ sleeping car _
breakfasted at Galesburg _ after
which for the first mine eyes
beheld the broad Prairie - at
2 P. M. had first sight of the
Father of Rivers & paid one dollar
to ride access it on the ice -
know all is slavery's improvidence
- no Depot at Palmyra _
no sleeping cars _ all in
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony takes a train to Quincy, sees the broad Prairie and the Father of Rivers, and notes the lack of amenities at Palmyra.

entries.fullText:
Splendid day -
Rode with Annie
to the Fort & called
on Gen. Curtis, - he
had left [f] at morning
for his new Post.
Milwaukie - his
wife is a real motherly
woman - & the widowed
daughter in Law, a sweet
delicate woman - The
Generals [?] was very
unaffected & unpleasant
to them - Got letters from
mother and girls & Merritt
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony rode with Annie to the Fort and called on Gen. Curtis in Leavenworth. She received letters from her mother, girls, and Merritt. She also mentioned Milwaukie and the General's wife and daughter-in-law.

entries.fullText:
Annie rode to Fort
with Mrs. Kendell - a
splendid day in
A. M - and took
me out 3 miles
on the Lawrence
road in P. M.
The country looks
better than I expected.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent a splendid day in Leavenworth with Annie and Mrs. Kendell. She also went out 3 miles on the Lawrence road and found the country to look better than expected.

entries.fullText:
Annie took me
riding on Salt
Lake Road -
her cold very
bad
entries.summaryText: Went riding on Salt Lake Road with Annie, her cold was very bad.

entries.fullText:
Annies Cold,
worse - no ride -
entries.summaryText: Annie's cold got worse, no ride taken.

entries.fullText:
Called on
Dr. Mayer - a
German Physician
like him very
much - he called
to see Annie -
began to rain
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony called on Dr. Mayer, a German physician, who visited Annie. It began to rain.

entries.fullText:
Rainy & snowy
Dr Mayer called
entries.summaryText: It was rainy and snowy. Dr. Mayer called.

entries.fullText:
Dr. Mayer
called again
The weather bright
and beautiful - he
prophesied it
would rain before
moring - Wagered a
pair of gloves -
entries.summaryText: Dr. Mayer visited and made a bet about the weather.

entries.fullText:
Still bright and
beautiful - the
bell ring rang & a boy
left a box - which
enclosed a pair
of gloves as compliments
of Dr. Mayer
entries.summaryText: Dr. Mayer sent a gift of gloves.

entries.fullText:
[Bright & beautiful
morning - Annie
took cousin Lucien
riding in the
morning -]
Annie not
able to ride - &
the mud too deep
entries.summaryText: Annie took cousin Lucien riding in the morning, but Annie was not able to ride due to the mud being too deep.

entries.fullText:
[Heavy Snow
Storm - Annie's
father John came
from the South -
Col. Montgomery of
Mound City, Kansas -
dined here & spent the
P. M. giving us history
of his South Carolina
and early Kansas experiences]
entries.summaryText: Annie's father John came from the South during a heavy snow storm. Col. Montgomery of Mound City, Kansas dined with them and spent the afternoon giving them history of his South Carolina and early Kansas experiences.

entries.fullText:
[Cold & windy & very
sowy; Cousin
Lucien Squier left
for the east- ]
Mr. Daniels [rode?]
but the mud
entries.summaryText: Cousin Lucien Squier left for the east.

entries.fullText:
Cloudy & very like
rain - Mr. and Mrs.
Wm Daniels left this
a.m. for their home
Iowa City- Iowa
entries.summaryText: Mr. and Mrs. Wm Daniels left for their home in Iowa City, Iowa.

entries.fullText:
Daniel returned
from Washington-
visited Rochester-
brot trunk with
bed, pillows, blankets
quilts, linen sheet,
tea spoons, Emerson's
works &c &c - and
good letter from
mother.
entries.summaryText: Daniel returned from Washington and visited Rochester. He brought a trunk with various items and a good letter from his mother.

entries.fullText:
Cousin Lucien
Squier came
at P.M. -business
sell "Axle Grease".
D.R. and Annie
took a ride to the
fort.
entries.summaryText: Cousin Lucien Squier came to visit and sell "Axle Grease". D.R. and Annie took a ride to the fort.

entries.fullText:
severe snow
storm - really
like an eastern
storm -
Annies brother
John Osborn came
this night -
Col Montgomery
of Mound City dined
with us - spent the P.M.
relating his experiences
in N. Carolina & early
Kansas times -
entries.summaryText: Severe snow storm, visit from Annie's brother and dinner with Col Montgomery of Mound City who shared his experiences in North Carolina and early Kansas times.

entries.fullText:
Cousin Lucien
left this morning
for the east -
snow deep & weather
cold
entries.summaryText: Cousin Lucien left for the east in deep snow and cold weather.

entries.fullText:
[Lucien Squier left
for the east -
weather cold and
heavy fall of snow]
entries.summaryText: Lucien Squier left for the east - weather cold and heavy fall of snow

entries.fullText:
Rev. Mr. Mitchell of
the M. E. Church
took tea with us -
is thoroughly for equality
to black men -
entries.summaryText: Rev. Mr. Mitchell of the M. E. Church took tea with us - is thoroughly for equality to black men

entries.fullText:
Cold, but bright --
Annie's brother John
left for Burlington
entries.summaryText: Annie's brother John left for Burlington on a cold but bright day.

entries.fullText:
[*Went to Mother in the A.M.*}
Beautiful day - President Lincoln begins
his new term. The
day is observed as a
national holiday.
In P.M. Annie's & self
made calls on Mrs. Dr.
Mayer, Mrs. Parker, Mrs.
Earle, Mrs. Wise, and Mrs.
Ball -- Ms. Mead of
the "Home" called - she
told us of the almost universal
infection of the ex-slave
women - child born
last week one mess of corruption
dead of course and one living still
letter from Sister [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends a beautiful day making calls with Annie and hearing about the infection of ex-slave women from Ms. Mead. She also receives a letter from her sister.

entries.fullText:
Splendid day -
Went to Colored Sabbath
School at Christian Church
- Mr. Crane, formerly of
Osawatomie is Superintendant
- Went to Congregational
Church with Mr. Brown
and his sister Mrs. Hand
- Col. Hoyt of the old
Kansas 7th was to dine
with us, but did not
come - D.R. and Annie
took a long ride in the
afternoon - got letter from
Mother Gula & Aaron -
All well & happy in their
new arrangements
Also letter from
Lucy Stone
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to Colored Sabbath School and Congregational Church, received letters from family and friends.

entries.fullText:
Bright & warm -
Annie called at Mrs. Parkers.
Eliza Ann (colored) began
plain sewing - Did
pretty well, but
not nice enough
for the little dresses
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony's assistant Annie visited Mrs. Parkers and Eliza Ann began plain sewing.

entries.fullText:
growing cold -
went shopping in
the afternoon -
Eliza Ann sewed this
day & took home with
her to make 1 sheet &
3 pair of pillow cases
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the weather getting colder, going shopping, and Eliza Ann sewing.

entries.fullText:
Coldest morning
of the season -
10 deg. below zero-
Such sudden
transitions from
bright spring days to
the intensest cold
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the coldest morning of the season and the sudden transition from bright spring days to intense cold.

entries.fullText:
Cold & windy
but relaxing -
entries.summaryText: Describes the weather as cold and windy but relaxing.

entries.fullText:
Quite warm & pleasant
Called at Primary
Colored School (Mrs.
Douglas') in the
morning -
I in afternoon
visited Mr. Langston's
school - 200 scholars
in one room - two
departments & two teachers
Called at Rev. Mr.
Mitchells - he was out
entries.summaryText: Describes the weather as quite warm and pleasant. Visited Primary Colored School and Mr. Langston's school. Called at Rev. Mr. Mitchells but he was out.

entries.fullText:
- cleaned Lounge
with alcohol & brushed
furniture all the A.M. -
Mr. Langston
called in P.M. - D.R.
and Annie took a ride -
In eve read in
the "Atlantic" for March
"The Popular Lecture" -
& Causes of Foreign Hate
toward America -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony cleaned and brushed furniture, read in the "Atlantic" for March, and had visitors Mr. Langston, D.R., and Annie.

entries.fullText:
Attended the Colored
Sunday School - Mr. Crane
of Osawatomie - Superintendent
- Gov. Arney at New
Mexico present - had
not slept in bed for the
last four weeks - Rode in
Stage over a thousand
miles - going to Washington
to negotiate about the
The Hostile Indians
Understandably afraid of
Bible Society or [Le ??]
[saving?] [Bible?]- In evn'g
wrote letters to Mother &
Lucy Stone & Lydia Mott
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended the Colored Sunday School and wrote letters to Mother, Lucy Stone, and Lydia Mott. Governor Arney was present and Mr. Crane of Osawatomie was the superintendent. Gov. Arney was going to Washington to negotiate about the Hostile Indians.

entries.fullText: Heavy Thunder Shower in the last night wrote an article on the Bible Society in the forenoon - In afternoon made second apron for John - Annie sewed all day - and it rained all day - in evening read Beecher on "Negro Suffrage" - wrote S. H. Camp - asking him to give Phillips his testimoy of Point Hudson & Gen Banks -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a thunder shower that happened the previous night and her activities for the day, including writing an article, making an apron, and reading about "Negro Suffrage". She also wrote a letter to S. H. Camp asking him to give Phillips his testimony of Point Hudson & Gen Banks.

entries.fullText: Another heavy Thunder Shower last night - partly cleared off during the day P. O. boy brought me the home letter Sister Mary, Mother Gula and Aaron the writers - also a letter from Parker Pillsbury and package of the "Broken Letter" from Detroit Standard came - wrote letter to S. H. Camp asking him to tell Phillips of Negroes Point Hudson & Gen Banks
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about another thunder shower that happened the previous night and receiving letters from family and friends, including a package of the "Broken Letter" from Detroit Standard. She also wrote a letter to S. H. Camp asking him to tell Phillips of Negroes Point Hudson & Gen Banks.

entries.fullText:
Snowed all day
Annie sewed very
steady all day -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the snow and Annie sewing.

entries.fullText:
Bright & pleasant
the snow vanished
in a twinkling -
Annie not well to day
had quite a talk
with D. R. till 10 oclock
- wrote an article
for the paper - and
a letter to clear
Ann Elizas artist
friend - Emma Gilbert
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the weather, Annie's health, a conversation with D.R., writing an article and a letter to clear Ann Elizas artist friend, Emma Gilbert.

entries.fullText:
Splendid day
In a.m. Annie
& self went down
town - in p.m.
the wind blowed
terrifically -
entries.summaryText: Annie and Susan went down town in Leavenworth on a windy day.

entries.fullText:
Said "Silver Marie"
came -
Called at
the House found
Mr. Brown very ill
Miss Mead going to
leave for home [?]
Met Mrs. Griswold
for the first - her husband
defended John
Brown at Harpers Ferry
entries.summaryText: Susan met Silver Marie, visited Mr. Brown who was ill, and met Mrs. Griswold for the first time who's husband defended John Brown at Harpers Ferry.

entries.fullText: Had Miss Norris' class at Colored Sabbath School - called at the Home - Mr. Brown ill - wrote a letter for him to Cousin Miss Anson Sapham -
entries.summaryText: Miss Norris' class at Colored Sabbath School, visited the Home, wrote a letter for Mr. Brown to Cousin Miss Anson Sapham.

entries.fullText: Leavenworth hard rain in A.M. Sam'l Ludlum and wife took tea with us - Silver ware had its christen'g - Severe rain in eve'g -
entries.summaryText: Hard rain in Leavenworth, had tea with Sam'l Ludlum and wife, christened silverware, severe rain in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Mrs Johnson - from
3 miles out, and her
brother Capt. Smith
took tea & spent the
evening Mrs. J. is the
first & only woman
I've met who speaks
of any question public
or private - prohibited or
religious - save the
frivolities of "Society" -
It was really refreshing
to see & hear a woman
who thinks & reads -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets Mrs. Johnson and her brother Capt. Smith, and is impressed by Mrs. Johnson's interest in public and private issues, unlike other women who only talk about frivolous topics.

entries.fullText:
D.R and Annie
went to theatre this
eve. Miss Gladstone the
Stage Lion - Annie
had to leave - got so
suffocated - such a crowd.
entries.summaryText: D.R and Annie went to the theatre to see Miss Gladstone, but Annie had to leave due to the crowd and feeling suffocated.

entries.fullText: Had Miss Norris Class at the colored Sabbath School in A.M. -- Went to Fort with Mrs. Daugton to spend day -- saw Colored Battery drill in morning - dined with Lieut. Wm Matthew's and in P.M. saw Colored Battery on dress parade with a Wisconsin veteran Battery -- two Rock Island Rebel companies & other white companies -- here black & white are equal Lieut Matthews marched out in line to salute act'g Col. Found letter from Mrs. Stanton
entries.summaryText: The author attended a class at a colored Sabbath School, went to a fort with Mrs. Daugton, saw a Colored Battery drill and on dress parade, dined with Lieut. Wm Matthew's, saw two Rock Island Rebel companies and other white companies, and found a letter from Mrs. Stanton.

entries.fullText:
Raining in morning
Called at Mr. Burnham
found Lieut Miner dead
then called on Rev.
Mr. Caldwell (Baptist)
his wife said my dear
father had made them
visits when in Leavenworth
four years ago--
Called also at brother
Turners (Methodist Col'd)
& talked about free schools
C's firing meet'g
went strong for D. R.
for Mayor --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mr. Burnham and finds Lieut Miner dead. She also visits Rev. Mr. Caldwell and brother Turner to talk about free schools and expresses support for D.R. for Mayor.

entries.fullText:
Attended funeral of
Lieut. Patrick Henry Miner
of Capt. H. Ford Douglas' (Col'd)
Battery -- burried with
military honors - Lieut. Wm
Matthews in Command
David R. Miner
voted for Mayor
by the regular Republican
delegation Commitee
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends the funeral of Lieut. Patrick Henry Miner and notes that David R. Miner was voted for Mayor by the regular Republican delegation Committee.

entries.fullText: Rode out with Annie in A.M. -- Ran into a big wagon on Delaware Street -- D.R. right there - his patience - his coolness with her fits and moods and [freaks?] were perfectly marvelous - Wrote article for bulletin on Lieut Miner -- Thomas Carey nominated as opposition by the [holters?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony rode out with Annie and ran into a big wagon on Delaware Street. D.R. was there and his patience and coolness with Annie's fits and moods were marvelous. She wrote an article for the bulletin on Lieut Miner and Thomas Carey was nominated as opposition by the [holters?].

entries.fullText: Wrote letters to Mrs. Mc Bride of Topeka - and R.P. at Boston Annie has a very sore throat - called at Dr. Mayers for medicine for her- D.R. spoke on 4th ward this eve - Capt. Jack Merrick took tea here on the way [hardly?] [?] [?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote letters to Mrs. Mc Bride and R.P. Annie had a sore throat and Susan called Dr. Mayers for medicine. D.R. spoke on 4th ward and Capt. Jack Merrick took tea at her place.

entries.fullText: Went riding with Annie in the A.M. Mrs. Erwin & O Brien called in P.M. Judge Delahay dined here - Oh shades of Jay & Ellsworth - [illigant?] Clar - than - theirn - yourn - knowed "My Old Woman" for wife - what small stuff judges are made of- Took another ride in P.M. - The Carney Party had large meeting this eveg- Called on Mrs. Smith and Annie at the Planters D.R spoke in 1st ward
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her day in Leavenworth, including riding with Annie, entertaining guests, and attending a political meeting.

entries.fullText: Beautiful, bright day
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony notes the weather in Leavenworth.

entries.fullText:
Sister Mary's birthday
- she is 38 -
entries.summaryText: Sister Mary's 38th birthday.

entries.fullText:
Elizabeth Ford Andrew Proudfit - Madison Wisc
Sarah Ford Robert N. Austin Milwaukee
Mary Streut Roddice -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about meeting with Elizabeth Ford Andrew Proudfit in Madison Wisc, Sarah Ford and Robert N. Austin in Milwaukee, and Mary Streut Roddice.
Susan B. Anthony did not write an entry on this day.

entries.fullText: Went Brother Mitchells - M.E. Church in the A.M. - and to Brother Caldwells (Baptist) Sunday School in P.M.
entries.summaryText: Attended church at Brother Mitchells and Sunday School at Brother Caldwells.

entries.fullText: At office in morning - met M. T. Conway just returned from Washington -
entries.summaryText: Met M. T. Conway who just returned from Washington.

entries.fullText: Rained all day didn't go the office - got letter from Merritt He is stationed at St. Louis again - [In P.M. went down town & to Mrs. Parkers with Annie -]
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from Merritt who is stationed in St. Louis again. Went downtown and to Mrs. Parkers with Annie in the afternoon.

entries.fullText: Spent morning in office John Rier of this City and Mr. Sturgeon of St. Louis dined with us - Mr. S. is Railroad Superintendent of the North Missouri Road - Sent Merritts letter to Mother In P.M. went down town with Annie - M. T Conway called -
entries.summaryText: John Rier and Mr. Sturgeon visited the office, Merritts letter was sent to Mother, and M. T Conway called.

entries.fullText: First gun fired on Sumter four years ago to day - - Spent forenoon in office -
entries.summaryText: The first gun was fired on Sumter four years ago today and the forenoon was spent in the office.

entries.fullText:
Fort Sumter Flag
raising today - just four
years since it was furled
both done by Maj Gen. Anderson
Beecher the high point -

Weather warmer but
clouding up for rain
entries.summaryText: Fort Sumter flag raising and weather update.

entries.fullText:
Morning Telegram
reported President
Lincoln assassinated
at Fords Theatre
in Washington - and
Sec. Seward stabbed
in his sick bed -
Stunning - soon
another that Lincoln
was dead -
Vice President
Johnson immediately
sworn in
entries.summaryText: Assassination of President Lincoln and stabbing of Sec. Seward, Vice President Johnson sworn in.

entries.fullText:
D.R. went to M.E.
Church - Mitchell gave
a stirring word -
John Osborn went
to the Irish Catholic
they did not mention
the occurrence -
I went to the Episcopal
merely mentioned
the fact -
In eve I called
at Colored M.E. &
Colored Baptist - but
the jam was too great -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to the Episcopal church and visited the Colored M.E. and Colored Baptist churches, but they were too crowded. D.R. went to M.E. Church and John Osborn went to the Irish Catholic church.

entries.fullText:
Wilkes Boothe
the murderer -
Seward not dead
Sent letter to
Gula & Mother
and Lydia Mott
and received letter
from Merritt and
Mrs. Wright of
Auburn -
Raining -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a letter from Merritt and Mrs. Wright of Auburn and sent letters to Gula, Mother, and Lydia Mott. Wilkes Boothe is the murderer and Seward is not dead. It was raining.

entries.fullText: Rainy
entries.summaryText: Rainy

entries.fullText:
Funeral services of
President Lincoln
at Washington & all
over the country -
very warm & sultry
- wrote letters in
P.M. to Mrs. Stanton,
Pillsbury & Phillips
Annie & self
had pleasant call
at Dr. Mayers in
evening -
entries.summaryText: Attended funeral services for President Lincoln in Washington, wrote letters in the afternoon, and had a pleasant call at Dr. Mayers in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Chilly forenoon -
Caft. M. Smith dined
with us
entries.summaryText: Captain M. Smith dined with Susan B. Anthony on a chilly forenoon.

entries.fullText: Cold, sleety, windy
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about the weather being cold, sleety, and windy.

entries.fullText:
State Fast day for the
Death of Lincoln,
Heard Liggitt
in the A.M.
attended Peoples
Meeting at [Laings?]
Hall in P.M.
Colored people took
front seats -
the pro slavery anti-negro
people dreadfully
shocked & outraged
entries.summaryText: Attended State Fast day for the Death of Lincoln, heard Liggitt speak in the morning, and attended a Peoples Meeting at [Laings?] Hall in the afternoon where colored people took front seats and pro slavery anti-negro people were shocked and outraged.

entries.fullText: Took tea at H. Griswold's - with J.R. Brown and sister - Mrs. Hand - & Rev. Mr. Woodward & wife - It is perfectly shocking how few of the Republicans are ready to give equal rights to black men -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took tea at H. Griswold's with J.R. Brown, Mrs. Hand, Rev. Mr. Woodward and his wife. She expresses her disappointment at how few Republicans are willing to give equal rights to black men.

entries.fullText: Letter from Sister Gula - the vacant place in her heart is ever felt - the dear Ann Eliza how she lives & is loved -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from Sister Gula expressing the ever-felt vacant place in her heart and mentioning Ann Eliza.

entries.fullText:
Writing article
on Special Providences
at
dusk called
on Mrs. Haviland
at the Home
She is quite ill.
Standard came
read Phillip Card
against disbanding
A.S. Societies at
midnight - he is
right - it is sad -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about writing an article on Special Providences, visiting Mrs. Haviland who is quite ill, and reading Phillip Card's article against disbanding A.S. Societies.

entries.fullText:
Sewed all day
didn't go out
read A.S. Standard
The disbanding
of the American A.
S. Society is fully
as untimely as
Gen. Grant and
Herrmans' granting
Parole & Pardon &
the whole Rebel
armies -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about sewing all day, reading the A.S. Standard, and her opinion on the disbanding of the American A.S. Society and the granting of Parole & Pardon & the whole Rebel armies by Gen. Grant and Herrmans.

entries.fullText:
Shower in A.M.
Called at Rev. Mr.
Mitchells, to see
Bible Concordance -
Bright & pleasant -
met M.F. Conway -
he goes east soon -
has a very sad face.
Gen. Sherman's
armistice has turned
the tide against him
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Rev. Mr. Mitchells to see Bible Concordance and meets M.F. Conway who has a sad face. She also mentions Gen. Sherman's armistice turning the tide against him.
No entry written on this day.

entries.fullText: Heard Rev. Mr. Reases in A.M. and Rev. W. Scott in P.M. and eve'g -
entries.summaryText: Attended church services and heard Rev. Mr. Reases and Rev. W. Scott.

entries.fullText: This afternoon spoke at a meeting of the Colored people at Turners Hall - in evening spoke at the African M E. Church
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at a meeting of the Colored people at Turners Hall and later at the African M E. Church.

entries.fullText: This evening J. C. Stone of this City struck brother D. R. in the eye with umbrella - cause a newspaper article on Stone's Danking House -
entries.summaryText: J. C. Stone struck brother D. R. in the eye with an umbrella due to a newspaper article on Stone's Danking House.

entries.fullText:
Did not go to
Church - tried to
write all day but
didn't get but
one sentence -
Congressman Sidney
Clarke dined here-
also Mr. Ishell of
the Conservative -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony did not go to church and tried to write all day but only got one sentence done. Congressman Sidney Clarke and Mr. Ishell of the Conservative dined with her.

entries.fullText:
Did not go to
Church - tried to
write all day but
didn't get but
one sentence -
Congressman Sidney
Clarke dined here-
also Mr. Ishell of
the Conservative -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony did not go to church and tried to write all day but only got one sentence done. Congressman Sidney Clarke and Mr. Ishell of the Conservative dined with her.

entries.fullText:
D.R. set W.P.
Allen (a bright mulatto)
to work setting
type this A.M. -
Two boys dropped
work & left - soon
a call for a Printers
Union meeting -
All left & noted the
throw must not be
allowed to work. They
wont admit him to
their union, and
won't allow him to
work because he
isn't a member -
entries.summaryText: D.R. sets W.P. Allen to work, but he is not allowed to work by the Printers Union because he is not a member.

entries.fullText:
No hope that Mr.
Allen will get work -
It is a burning, blistering
shame - time however
will surely right the wrong.
Got a letter from
Parker Pillsbury, from
Allray also a note from
[Lydia Moth] - all going
to [M. Joh] - To day is the
business meeting that
decides the fate of
the American A. S. Soviet -
Mailed letter to
mother this A.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from Parker Pillsbury and a note from Lydia Moth. She also mentions the fate of the American A. S. Soviet and mails a letter to her mother.

entries.fullText: Be
entries.summaryText: Journal entry from May 10, 1865.
Journal entry from May 11, 1865.

entries.fullText: Began on a cord of wood cut short & split fine - $15 Report said Col. Dennison with several of his cronies was lying in wait for brother D.R. with intent to shoot him
entries.summaryText: Report of Col. Dennison and cronies planning to shoot D.R.

entries.fullText: Col. J. R. Dennison attacked brother D.R. at 5 11 - P.M. - shooting occurred - Dennison hit in the leg -
entries.summaryText: Col. J. R. Dennison attacked D.R. and was hit in the leg.

entries.fullText:
Began on a cord
of wool cut short
split fine - $5 -
Report said Col.
Jamison with several
of his cronies was
lying in wait for
brother J. N. with
intent to shoot him
entries.summaryText: Report of Col. Jamison and his cronies lying in wait to shoot brother J. N.

entries.fullText:
Col. J. R. Dennison
attacked brother D.R.
at 511- P. M. - shooting
occurred -- -- Dennison
hit in the leg -
entries.summaryText: Report of Col. J. R. Dennison attacking brother D.R. and getting hit in the leg during a shooting.

entries.fullText:
Got good letter
from Mother and
wrote Mother and
Merritt -
The fears of
brother's D.R's friends
are very great
entries.summaryText: Received a good letter from Mother, wrote to Mother and Merritt. The fears of brother's D.R's friends are very great.

entries.fullText:
W.G.W.
Mrs. Emma
of Omaha - N.J. - sent
basket to Dollie by this [?]
the Mother of Mrs Graves
of Washington D.C. who was
this far toward home - D.R.
boarded with her last winter
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Emma from Omaha, N.J. sent a basket to Dollie, who is the mother of Mrs. Graves from Washington D.C. and who was this far toward home. D.R. boarded with her last winter.

entries.fullText:
Attended M.E.
colored Sunday
school picnic-
entries.summaryText: Attended M.E. colored Sunday school picnic.

entries.fullText:
Sewed all the morning.
Daniel went
to market for
the first time -
Col. Jennison
able to ride out
he threatens to
shoot D.R. still
Rained this evening
entries.summaryText: Susan sewed in the morning and Daniel went to market for the first time. Col. Jennison was able to ride out and threatened to shoot D.R. It rained in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Cool, bright & beautiful -
wrote letters to
mother - Merritt & Mary -
wore white Garibaldi
waist for the
first time.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the weather, writing letters to her mother, Merritt, and Mary, and wearing a white Garibaldi waist for the first time.

entries.fullText: National Fast Day for death of Pres. Lincoln. Capt. H. Ford Douglass' Battery had Grave meeting at the Fort - large number 1000 or more colored people & some hundreds of white. - Capt. Douglas, Col. Jeries - C.R. Langston, S. B. Anthony Major Bowen, Lieut. Mathews spoke & Col. Rev. Caldwell prayed. Weather very hot, dry, windy & dusty.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a National Fast Day meeting in Leavenworth for the death of President Lincoln. She attends a meeting at Fort with Capt. H. Ford Douglass' Battery where several people spoke and prayed.

entries.fullText: SATURDAY, JUNE 3, 1865.

very hot & dusty&
windy - didn't go
out to Church -
wrote letters to
mother, L. Mott -
Anna very smart
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the weather and not going to church. She also mentions writing letters to her mother and L. Mott, and notes that Anna is doing well.

entries.fullText:
Awfully hot &
dusty - strong
wind - that filled
the house & every
thing with dust -
never saw
dust to match
anywhere before
Got letter from
Lydia Mott - she
has had severe time
with her lungs again
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the hot and dusty weather and receiving a letter from Lydia Mott who has been having trouble with her lungs.

entries.fullText:
[Several splendid
showers - all nature
seems refreshed - Got
invitation to speak
on the 4th of July at
Otumwa, Coffee Co.
Sent off letter
to Merritt & one to
D.R.]
Very hot & dusty
D.R. took me to
the Fort to see Capt.
Douglass wife - Mrs. D. had
miscarriage - Thursday night
after the grove meeting
(Hope you won't miscarry again)
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about receiving an invitation to speak on the 4th of July in Otumwa, Coffee Co. and visiting Capt. Douglass' wife at the Fort who had a miscarriage after the grove meeting.

entries.fullText:
D. R. got telegram
from J. M. that he
couldn't get out of
the army & was
ordered off --
Had blue day -
Mountains on every
side - among them
could see snow.
Merritts wife & children
were to [?] comfortably
located - hope J.M.
will come this way -
rained at evening -
entries.summaryText: Received a telegram from J.M. that he couldn't get out of the army and was ordered off. Had a blue day surrounded by mountains and rain in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Splendid showers
weather cooled,
all nature refreshed
dust laid low --
Got invitation
to speak at Otumwa
Coffee Co. Kan.
the 4th of July - most
too far to go this hot
weather, & southward too -
Sent letter to D.M.
at St. Louis - alas none
to PP. New York
entries.summaryText: Received an invitation to speak at Otumwa Coffee Co. Kan. on the 4th of July but it was too far to go in the hot weather. Sent a letter to D.M. at St. Louis but none to PP. New York.

entries.fullText:
Colored Peoples
Meeting at Harmony
Hall - to
organize movement
for equal Suffrage.
The Morris Turner
Newton party broke
solemn pledge not
to introduce their
old quarrel - hence
the object of the meeting
was defeated -
entries.summaryText: Meeting at Harmony Hall to organize movement for equal Suffrage. The Morris Turner Newton party broke solemn pledge not to introduce their old quarrel - hence the object of the meeting was defeated.

entries.fullText:
Rain nearly every
day of the entire
week -
entries.summaryText: Rain nearly every day of the entire week.

entries.fullText:
Cool & pleasant
shower at dusk -
Heard Rev.
W. Scott in A.M.
No letters the last
week -
Pres. Johnson
is bound to leave
the five millions loyal
blacks of the South powerless
in the hands of
the eight millions
disloyal whites armed
with [?ruttet], & ballot -
entries.summaryText: Cool & pleasant shower at dusk. Heard Rev. W. Scott in A.M. No letters the last week. Pres. Johnson is bound to leave the five millions loyal blacks of the South powerless in the hands of the eight millions disloyal whites armed with [?ruttet], & ballot.

entries.fullText: THURSDAY, JUNE 29, 1865.

Took stage for
Topeka at 7 A.M.
Splendid ride,
good company - Butterfield
of Overland Dispatch
one - great
talk on politics,
negro equality and
temperance - Maj.
Scott Anthony one,
arrived at Cousin
Paulina [?]
Foster [?] at
8 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony took a stage to Topeka and had a good ride with Butterfield of Overland Dispatch. She had a great talk on politics, negro equality, and temperance with Maj. Scott Anthony. She arrived at Cousin Paulina Foster's place at 8 P.M.

entries.fullText:
Spoke to full house
in M.E. Church
Col. Richie President
of meeting -
negro suffrage
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at a meeting in M.E. Church, with Col. Richie as the President of the meeting, discussing negro suffrage.

entries.fullText:
Spoke to the
Colored Sabbath
School -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at the Colored Sabbath School.

entries.fullText: Had pleasant stage ride - grand old prairies are perfectly splendid - and the timber skirted creeks are delightful - crossed the Maria De Ligne 19 miles from source and 40 above Ossawatomie -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony describes a pleasant stage ride through prairies and creeks, mentioning the Maria De Ligne and Ossawatomie locations.

entries.fullText: Ottumwa Celebration - grand mass gathering. Hon. Sid. Clarke M. C. the orator. Spoke just a hour on Pres. Johnsons Mississippi Reconstruction Proclamation -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a grand mass gathering in Ottumwa, where Hon. Sid. Clarke speaks for an hour on Pres. Johnsons Mississippi Reconstruction Proclamation.

entries.fullText: Spent day at M. Cox writing out speech
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at M. Cox writing out a speech.

entries.fullText: At J. Cox- Writing all day on speech
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at J. Cox's writing all day on a speech.

entries.fullText:
Mr. & Mrs. Cox
Mr. & Mrs. Rankin
self and Mrs. Osborn
visited at Lanes
eight miles out in
the prairie. Met there
Mr. & Mrs. Benedict
who spent the winter
of 55 in first farm
in Ottumwa.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Lanes and meets Mr. & Mrs. Benedict who spent the winter of 55 in first farm in Ottumwa.

entries.fullText:
Hack from
Ottumwa to Topeka
- rickety old thing. just kept ahead
of tremendous rains
all day - Found
Cousin Paulina
all right - Letters
from Sister Annie,
L. Mott, H.B. Stanton,
Merritt & Mother & Gula
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Ottumwa to Topeka in a rickety old hack and finds Cousin Paulina all right. She also receives letters from Sister Annie, L. Mott, H.B. Stanton, Merritt, Mother, and Gula.

entries.fullText: Did not go out to church - called at Col. John Ritchies at dusk
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony did not go to church and visited Col. John Ritchies at dusk.

entries.fullText: Dined at Col. Ritchies - Cousin P. and son John G. Otis - a Mrs. Ridgeway - widow with two little girls - a Swedenborgian in religion - very cultivated - Spoke at Temperance meeting in M.E: Church in evening - hard work no response.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony dined at Col. Ritchies with Cousin P. and son John G. Otis, a Mrs. Ridgeway, and spoke at a Temperance meeting in M.E. Church in the evening with no response.

entries.fullText: Worked all day to copy Ottumwa speech- Col. Clarkson & new wife - and Mrs Ritchies and Mr Ridgeway called
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony worked on copying a speech and received visitors in Topeka.

entries.fullText: Topeka to Lawrence by stage in P.M. couldn't find the Roberts - so went to John Speare's- he gone - wife not well - six children from 22 years to 2 - lost two boys in the raid two years ago - still not ready to let the negroes vote -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony traveled to Lawrence and visited John Speare's family, who were not yet ready to support voting rights for African Americans.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Speers May
took me to find
Mrs. Col. Roberts.
She was gone out.
- so reluctantly returned
to Speers - She
has no girl & it seemed
an outrage to add to
her burdens. but
no alternatives but
the Hotel -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mrs. Col. Roberts in Lawrence but she was not home, so she returned to Mrs. Speers May's house.

entries.fullText:
Spoke in Unitarian
Church this
eve- good audience
but my spirit had
been so thoroughly
chilled by finding
no genuine Anti Slavery
friends, that I spoke
at great effort. -
tried to get into Hotel
but no room - Mr.
S.N. Simpson took me
to his home - nice place
but Mrs. S. had no girl
no spare room -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony speaks at the Unitarian Church in Lawrence and stays at Mr. S.N. Simpson's home since there was no room at the hotel.

entries.fullText:
Mr. & Mrs S. took me
to see reception of
the 12th reg't - heard
Clarke, but not Lane, speak
had nice dinner
In P.M. Mr. S.
announced that he had
provided me a place
at Mrs. Jenkins - mother
of the man Gen. [?]
shot seven years ago -
turned the daughter
out of their [?] - So
it seems Lawrence has
no place for me.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a reception and dinner with Mr. & Mrs S. and hears Clarke speak. Mr. S. provides her a place to stay at Mrs. Jenkins' house.

entries.fullText:
Congregational Church
with D. N. Simson -
thence to colored Sunday
school - very bright young &
old - felt wretched.
ate no dinner. Took
cup of Tea & bit of cracker
Then at 3 P.M. spoke
at Congregational [?] col
people--full house.
White read 7th Jeremiah
& showed how each
generation has done more
than the Fathers [?]
a greeting from the colored
people--Called at
Clarkes--Hon. Sidney
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends church and Sunday school with D. N. Simson. She speaks at Congregational [?] to a full house and visits Clarkes and Hon. Sidney.

entries.fullText:
Lawrence to Leavenworth
by cars to Wyandott
and both Emilie
Hon S. Clarke in company
f[?] Mrs. Nichols
[?] Z[?] it
is going to rain
arrived about 5 P.M.,
found all well
and doing well -
found letter
from P.P. --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Lawrence to Leavenworth with Emilie, Hon S. Clarke, and Mrs. Nichols. She arrives in Wyandott and finds a letter from P.P.

entries.fullText:
Got letter from
Mrs. Stanton from
Johnstown - sent
one from Phillips
to her - he say "tell
Susan to come east - there
is work for her
to do --
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a letter from Mrs. Stanton in Johnstown and a message from Phillips telling her to come east for work.

entries.fullText:
Rainy so didn't
go out - wrote
to mother of
Merritts being on
the way to Omaha
It's cruel as
death to retain
that old 7th Kansas
Regiment to go out
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about not going out due to the rain and writing to the mother of Merritts who is on the way to Omaha. She also expresses her opinion on retaining the old 7th Kansas Regiment to go out.

entries.fullText:
to the Plains to
fight Indians &
the boys felt very
much wronged -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about going to the Plains to fight Indians and how the boys felt wronged.

entries.fullText:
Went down town
to try & stir up
the work of getting
up a nice lunch
for the old 7th
boys - but failed
and the boy were
sadly disappointed
for they had hoped
for it -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went down town to try and get a nice lunch for the old 7th boys but failed.

entries.fullText:
Got telegram that
Steamer David Tatum
would land at Fort
about noon - it halted
at city - so I took [?]
up the river - Mary
landed to see House
and baby - and rode up
to Fort with Cousin Edwin
& Dan & Annie took Dollie
with them. - they both
invited Dollie to come
back with me.
Merritt looks weather
worn - Mary poorer
than ever before - the
boy Daniel fat, plump &
a good baby-- spoke to
the boys on board in the
evening - they seemed pleased -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony received a telegram that Steamer David Tatum would land at Fort, but it halted at the city. She went up the river with Mary and landed to see House and baby. She rode up to Fort with Cousin Edwin, and Dan and Annie took Dollie with them. Merritt looks weather-worn, Mary poorer than ever before, and the boy Daniel fat, plump, and a good baby. She spoke to the boys on board in the evening, and they seemed pleased.

entries.fullText:
Steamer David Tatum
Arrived at Saint
Joseph about 3 P.M.
decided to stop - and
not to take Dollie -
- got to Hotel before thought
of fruit came to me - looked
& saw boat standing - then
ran & bought two cans of
peaches & rushed back to
boat to find it in the middle
of the stream - so strange
that I should forget it - I
can't get over it - wrote
letter to mother - then walked
about town - saw Colored
Baptist ministers - Adam
Dimmitt, promised to
speak for them soon -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived at Saint Joseph and decided not to take Dollie. She bought two cans of peaches and wrote a letter to her mother. She also saw Colored Baptist ministers, Adam Dimmitt, and promised to speak for them soon.

entries.fullText:
Returned to Leavenworth -
found all
right at 5 P.M.
Purchased basket, doll,
2 little P. [?], cologne,
soap, tooth brush - ring -
for four dollars & sent to
Omaha by Mrs. Emma
Homan of that city to
Dollie -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony returned to Leavenworth and purchased items for four dollars and sent them to Dollie in Omaha through Mrs. Emma Homan.

entries.fullText:
Annie & self
called on Mrs. H.
Griswold, Mrs.
Judge Sears, and [?]
Mrs. Scott -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Annie visited Mrs. H. Griswold, Mrs. Judge Sears, and Mrs. Scott.

entries.fullText:
Went to hear Mr.
Siggett -
In evening Lieut.
Wm. Mathews, and
Mr. Merrill called -
white knocked down
Mr. Merrill without
provocation - Police
refused to go and to aid
then followed a set
to in which the
colored people drove
the whites off the
ground -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to hear Mr. Siggett and in the evening Lieut. Wm. Mathews and Mr. Merrill called. A white man knocked down Mr. Merrill without provocation and the police refused to help. This led to a confrontation where the colored people drove the whites off the ground.

entries.fullText:
Fine day -
Bother [Ian?] gave
account of fight in
this P. M.'s Bulletin
of Tuesday Times pronounce
it the fiction
of a crazed brain
entries.summaryText: Bother [Ian?] gave account of fight in this P. M.'s Bulletin of Tuesday Times pronounce it the fiction of a crazed brain

entries.fullText:
fine day
31 years today since
Emancipation took effect
- and 27 since
total, immediate - in
the British W. Indies -
Large gathering at the
Grove - not a speaker
there save myself.
Spoke mainly of the
changed condition of
of the colored people &
their new rights & new
duties. very attentive
Walked up & back -
entries.summaryText: 31 years today since Emancipation took effect - and 27 since total, immediate - in the British W. Indies - Large gathering at the Grove - not a speaker there save myself. Spoke mainly of the changed condition of of the colored people & their new rights & new duties. very attentive Walked up & back -

entries.fullText:
Called this
A.M. at Brother
Turner's & Caldwells
began raining
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visited Brother Turner's and Caldwells on a rainy day.

entries.fullText:
Raining still
Hon. Sidney Clarke
to dinner - he
advised me not to
bring in W. Rights -
I showed I had done
so only by of illustrating
the point that no class
can be trusted to
legislate for another
though that other be
wife, daughter, mother, sister
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony has dinner with Hon. Sidney Clarke and they discuss not bringing in W. Rights.

entries.fullText:
Raining--warm showers
Took stage at 10.30
very rough. had a long
wait at the Western
R.R. Station. Found
Planters Hotel full -
sent note to Mr. Adams
Editor Free Press. He
came & took me to
John M. Crowells - an
ex. Mayor of Atchison
- Bright cordial welcome
began to feel my mercury
rise - Senator D.C. Pomeroz
called - Said I must
speak before I left.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels to Atchison, has trouble finding a hotel, meets with Mr. Adams and John M. Crowells, and is asked to speak by Senator D.C. Pomeroz.

entries.fullText: Went to Pomeroy's church in A.M. sat with him - In P.M. spoke to a fine audience of the colored people - six of them subscribed for Anti slavery standard
entries.summaryText: Attended church and spoke to a fine audience of six colored people who subscribed to Anti slavery standard.

entries.fullText: Spoke to the white people this evening & not a colored person came - they don't venture - except specially invited never crowd themselves. Had a hard time thoughts, nor words would come - but I staggered through it - was too bad - had a large sprinkling of speech
entries.summaryText: Spoke to a white audience, no colored people came. Had a hard time with thoughts and words.

entries.fullText:
Left Mrs. Crowells at
4 P.M. - She gave me her
history - a strange one -
lived in hateful marriage
15 years - had very dear
friendship with John B
Gough - meantime -
then went to California
got Divorce and
married Crowell -
had small audience
at St. Joseph - the Bell
very helpful
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with Mrs. Crowells in St. Joseph, who shares her history of a difficult marriage and friendship with John B Gough before getting a divorce and marrying Crowell.

entries.fullText:
Judge P. Bliss called
and invited to take
at his house - which
I did - very pleasant
family - they came from
Illyria Ohio - J.W.
Langston studied
law with him -
spoke to colored
in eve - notice small
my letter to Rev Adam
Dimmitt did not reach him
mailed letter to P.P.
with the six Atchison
subscribers
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Judge P. Bliss in St. Joseph and speaks to colored people in the evening. She also mentions sending letters to Rev Adam Dimmitt and P.P. regarding Atchison subscribers.

entries.fullText:
arrived at 5 A.M.
Stopped at Harry's Hotel
left little carpet bag at Depot
walked back after it
Senot letters to Col.
Asper and Rev.
Bratten - Asper came
decided to have meeting
in Court House--Editor
Harbaugh sent word that
if I wouldn't lash him for
his article he'd print me
handbills - Mrs. P Brinkerhoff
came & took me home with her
& thankful was I -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony arrived in Chillicothe, Mo. from St. Joseph. She sent letters to Col. Asper and Rev. Bratten. Asper came and they decided to have a meeting in the Court House. Editor Harbaugh sent word that he would print her handbills if she wouldn't lash him for his article. Mrs. P Brinkerhoff came and took her home.

entries.fullText:
Cloudy & in a deluging
rain - meeting fair size
mostly men - Mrs. B. took
me to see Mrs. Heckman
Sunday & Day school teacher
of the Blacks - told me of
their marvelous progress
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a meeting in Chillicothe with mostly men. Mrs. B. took her to see Mrs. Heckman, a Sunday and Day school teacher of the Blacks, who told her of their marvelous progress.

entries.fullText: Raining but not cloudy - spoke on Free Schools this eve- had good audience of men mainly
entries.summaryText: Spoke on Free Schools to a good audience of mainly men in Chillicothe on a rainy day.

entries.fullText: Dark cloudy day spoke to five audience of colored people in a tobacco factory near depot - some white people present - took collection of $6.25 - the colored peoples perception as to their soul[?] friends is quick & correct
entries.summaryText: Spoke to a small audience of colored people in a tobacco factory near the depot in Chillicothe, where some white people were present. Collected $6.25. Noted that colored people have a quick and correct perception of their soul friends.

entries.fullText:
got to depot at
8 A.M. but no train
until 7 P.M. breakfasted
& dined at Brinkerhoff -
& took tea at an old
colored mans [?]
Samuel Jett -
got to Macon at
1 in the A.M. - had
tedious time to get
place to sleep - at last
found shelter at Mrs. Bolander's
- just a slab house -
- they are poor whites - [?]
[?] negroes
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Chillicothe to Macon City, encountering delays and finding shelter at Mrs. Bolander's, a poor white family's slab house.

entries.fullText:
called at colored school
teacher Mrs. Molloy -
in the old Harris Hotel
place been used for
soldiers barracks, and
dreadfully filthy -
Spoke to colored people
in same building in eve -
They don't seem as
intelligent as those of
[?]
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mrs. Molloy, a colored school teacher, and speaks to other colored people in the old Harris Hotel, which was used for soldiers barracks and is dreadfully filthy.

entries.fullText:
Spoke in M.E.
Church - good audience
Rev. Mr. Pace thought
me very severe on
the M.E. Church -
that I didn't except
it - it had always been
anti slavery, its discipline -
so had the Constitution
of the nation - I told him
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spoke at the M.E. Church in Macon City and had a conversation with Rev. Mr. Pace about the church's stance on anti-slavery.

entries.fullText:
Severe threatening of Dirrahea
- called at Mrs. Molloy
colored school & at Proctors
lay in bed two or three hours
took tea & Rev. Mr. Pace's
and spoke in the
evening -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visited Mrs. Molloy's colored school and Proctors in Macon City, and spoke in the evening after experiencing severe diarrhea.

entries.fullText:
Macon City to St. Louis
took North Missouri R.R.
about 11 arrived at 8 OC
Stopped Planters House
entries.summaryText: Travel from Macon City to St. Louis, including taking the North Missouri R.R. and staying at the Planters House.

entries.fullText:
St. Louis
called on Emile
Pretorias - not in -
sent card to I. H.
Sturgeon, Pres. N.M.R.R.
Frank Robinson called
to say his wife had gone
east with her father Mr. [ Juna?]
Rev. M.M. Clarke called -
am to speak in his Church
tomorrow Sunday P.M.
entries.summaryText: Activities in St. Louis, including visiting Emile, attempting to visit Pretorias, sending a card to I. H. Sturgeon, receiving news from Frank Robinson, and being scheduled to speak at Rev. M.M. Clarke's church the following day.

entries.fullText:
St. Louis at
Mrs. Dummon's - 208 - 7th Street
Mr. Elliot - Unitarian in
A.M. - In P.M. spoke to
the Color'd people in
their old slave church
- in eve, went back to
Planter's House - best
economy to pay most money -
no letters from Leavenworth -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits St. Louis, speaks to the Color'd people in their old slave church, and stays at Planter's House.

entries.fullText:
Planter's - St. Louis
called on Sturgeon and
Pretorius - both out -
visited Freedmens rooms
& the St. Louis Library
Saw Harriet Hosmer's
Cenci, Enone & Puck
wrote letters to Rochester
& Leavenworth
Had very small meeting
had sudden attack of diarrhea
while speaking had to close
suddenly & all night thought of
Dear Ann Eliza -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits St. Louis, sees Harriet Hosmer's Cenci, Enone & Puck, and writes letters to Rochester and Leavenworth.

entries.fullText:
Mr. Sturgeon
gave me a pass to
go to Chicago [?]
Alton & Springfield
Mrs. Henry Turner -
made calls with me
in P.M.
Mr. Clark called &
gave me $3 as compensation
for lectures -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony receives a pass to travel to Chicago and visits Alton and Springfield. She makes calls with Mrs. Henry Turner and receives $3 as compensation for lectures.

entries.fullText:
Took cars at 6.30 A.M.
via Alton - saw the
spot where Lovejoy was
shot in 1837 for his
advocacy of freedom -
Called at Springfield
dine at Mrs. Parker's, a
friend Brother Turners
she had bought herself
for $650 - a daughter for $128
another for $400 a son [?]
and since paid for her
house & lot in D.[?] - all
by washing & ironing with
her own hands
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from St. Louis to Springfield and sees the spot where Lovejoy was shot. She dines at Mrs. Parker's and learns about her impressive financial accomplishments through hard work.

entries.fullText:
Took cars at 8 last
evening - a woman
thief pressed up to
me & took from my
pocket this book - I
grabbed her arm not
very gently & told her to
deliver - she [?] [?]
but the book dropped to
the platform -
arrived at uncles
about 9 o clock - called
in P.M at Mrs. Loomis
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony takes a train to Chicago and has a book stolen from her pocket by a woman thief, but she manages to retrieve it. She arrives at her uncle's house and visits Mrs. Loomis in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Staid at aunts
all day & tried to
sleep up & talk
up and get rested
generally - letter from
sister Mary - Mother
left at Grandmothers
Hannah gone to visit
& come home with her
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day resting and visiting her aunt in Chicago. She receives a letter from her sister Mary and learns that her mother is at her grandmother's house and that Hannah has gone to visit and will return with her.

entries.fullText:
Called at Mrs.
Loomis - Mrs.
Douglass called
with me at the
Freedman's Commission
Sign office-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony called at Mrs. Loomis with Mrs. Douglass and went to the Freedman's Commission Sign office.

entries.fullText:
Uncle A walked
with me almost
to Mr.s Loomis' -
Found Mrs. Tracy
Butler there - she is
the same managing
woman - found the
Liberator here - & one by
good Editorial from
Mr. Garrison
Heard Gen Howards
lecture in Bryan Hall
in the Freedmen
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony met with Mrs. Tracy Butler and read an editorial from Mr. Garrison in the Liberator. She also attended a lecture by Gen Howards in Bryan Hall about the Freedmen.

entries.fullText: Called at Sherman House - saw Gen. Howard - Supertd of Freedmen's Bureau talk with Mrs. Haveland & Cutler & Cobb on freedmen & poor whites. Had fine audience in Quinn's Chapel - "Republican" reported my speech -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Sherman House and Quinn's Chapel in Chicago, meets with Gen. Howard, Mrs. Haveland, Cutler, and Cobb to discuss freedmen and poor whites, and gives a speech that is reported by the "Republican".

geographicalLocations: Uncle A. T. Dickinson's 110 S. Green
entries.fullText: Went from Mrs. J.M. Loomis - 462 State Street to Uncle A. T. Dickinson's 110 S. Green. Had a talk at eve with Melissa & aunt A.E. on the duty of all women to get themselves our independent purse - that it was poor economy for Melissa to just help manage home when she could earn 8 to 10 dollars a week by Teaching &c &c - to my utter surprise found I had hurt Aunt A.E. feelings badly
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mrs. J.M. Loomis and Uncle A. T. Dickinson in Chicago, has a conversation with Melissa and Aunt A.E. about the importance of women being financially independent, and unintentionally hurts Aunt A.E.'s feelings.

entries.fullText:
Took train at 8.20
arrived at 12.30-
Cousin Susan Hoxie
Richardson & I had
not met in 25 years
found each other
changed, but still in
sympathy together--
She & her husband
are interested in all
reform questions. It is a
real comfort to see them.
entries.summaryText: Met Cousin Susan Hoxie and her husband in Chicago after 25 years and discussed reform questions.

entries.fullText:
At Cousin Susan's
[Mrs. Shephe] George's
sister Abbey, cousin
Susan and Jeff took
tea at Mrs. Lignor's -
a cousin of Mary Doty's
& distant relative of the
Anthony's-
Cousin Susan
is a noble woman
has much of her
mothers sense of
justice with large
self control-
entries.summaryText: Had tea with relatives and discussed Cousin Susan's noble character.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Heyden of E.
took me to Ottawa-
found Cousin Ira
Howe's easily - he
is in feeble health and
low spirits - wife
out on a visit
Found A. D. Standards
of 5.12.19 - but
no better-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Cousin Ira Howe in Ottawa and meets with Mrs. Heyden and A. D. Standards.

entries.fullText:
About noon, Cousin
Eliza's sister Ms. Chapman
& son & Cousin
arrived from Dover
Plains - Dutchess N.Y
Fearfully hot & dry-
about time Cousin Ann
took me round to see
the city and call on
Mr. Groner - found him
out- he called Sunday
& I was at church -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Ottawa and meets with Cousin Eliza's sister, Ms. Chapman, and Cousin Ann. She also visits the city and tries to call on Mr. Groner.

entries.fullText: Went to Baptist Church with cousin Ira - Rev. Colman disavowed the [?] atonement. Said there was not one [?] less suffering for him because of the blood of Christ. This seemed to me a new phase for Orthodoxy. Byron Home came in P.M. I went home with him to his old farm and home.
entries.summaryText: Attended Baptist Church with cousin Ira and heard Rev. Colman disavow the atonement, visited Byron Home in the afternoon.

entries.fullText: Had a hard time to sleep for mosquitoes and wretched bed. Everything showed a lack of taste, skill or will in the house. Byron's wife's brother, Martin Trainsbridge drove me down to Ottawa. He Was in Sherman's Army. One of Jeff C. Davis Confed. who burned the bridge at Savannah and turned back the 10,000 slaves to cruel fates. Shower came up just at dark, which defeated meeting.
entries.summaryText: Had a difficult night's sleep, traveled to Ottawa with Martin Trainsbridge who was in Sherman's Army and burned the bridge at Savannah, but a shower prevented a meeting.

entries.fullText:
(Cool)
Cousin Ira Howe
took me back to Ottawa
cloudy & cool, but very
pleasant-- he is very sad
over his Son Byron's
Marriage--
Arrived at Cousin
Susan's at 12:30. had
splendid dinner-- She gets
up everything so good & in
such good order--
Had heavy shower
from one to four-- then
Cousin Ira started back--
Had small meeting
at Earlville Hall-- & made
a labored talk--
entries.summaryText: Cousin Ira Howe took Susan B. Anthony back to Ottawa. They had dinner at Cousin Susan's and Susan attended a small meeting at Earlville Hall.

entries.fullText:
Earlville to Chicago
Cousins George & Susan
gave up going to C. -
an old creditor has
sued them. They are not
quite sure that everything
is safe from his suit--
they failed eight years ago--
Niece Ann Eliza's
last well day, one year ago--
Gula staid at mother's
to tea. A. E. ate baked
sweet apples-- had [young]
of N.Y. to tea--knew
of no other cause for
her attack.
entries.summaryText: Cousins George and Susan did not go to Chicago due to an old creditor suing them. Niece Ann Eliza had an attack after eating baked sweet apples and having a visitor from New York for tea.

entries.fullText:
Aunt A. E. and
Mrs. Frazer of Dayton
of Ohio and her brother Willie
and self started for
state fair - began to
rain, Aunt and Self returned -
called at Mrs
Loomis.
Sister Annie's
letter last night
of of her father's sickness -
her brother John had gone
home and was to telegraph
back and she, D. A. were to
go on, if the doctor thought
her father would live
for her to get them
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her Aunt A. E. and Mrs. Frazer of Dayton went to the state fair in Chicago but had to return due to rain. They visited Mrs. Loomis. Susan received a letter from her sister Annie about their father's sickness and plans to go see him.

entries.fullText:
Aunt A. E. and
self took dinner at
Cousin Hannah Dickenson
Boyle's - in P.M. wrote to
Sister Annie Mary Luther
and the home folks.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and her Aunt A. E. had dinner at Cousin Hannah Dickenson Boyle's in Chicago. Susan wrote letters to her sister Annie Mary Luther and the home folks.

entries.fullText: Uncle A. J. went with me to P.O. got letter from P.P. and thence to Galens Depot. Cousin Nathan [J?]. An [?] [crowd?]. [Nate?]. Fair people going home. Found Lydia [Birdsell?] gone to her sister. Samil Albertson so went on. They had a carpet bag [bee?]. had a cordial reception. returned to Birdsalls. Samil tried M. E. Minister for Church. he would not grant it, nor read notice of it. Brother Merritt worked for Mr. James Birdsall 4 years ago. the summer he went to Chicago.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Chicago to Sterling with Uncle A. J. and Cousin Nathan. She meets with Samil Albertson and visits Lydia Birdsell's sister. Samil tries to get a M. E. Minister for Church but is unsuccessful. Brother Merritt worked for Mr. James Birdsall 4 years ago.

entries.fullText: William E. Lukens called early. went out and engaged [C?] for meeting this evening. very heavy showers all day. had pretty fair audience at evening
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony meets with William E. Lukens and engages [C?] for a meeting in the evening. There are heavy showers all day but a pretty fair audience shows up in the evening.

entries.fullText:
Sterling to Genesee Grove
to Uncle John Anthonys
John Albertson, has
hand of Uncle Elias
De [Garuro's?} daughter
Ann. took me to
Uncle Johns. found
all well and seemingly
glad to see me.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Sterling, Genesee Grove, and Uncle John Anthony's. She meets with John Albertson, Uncle Elias, De [Garuro's?] daughter, and Ann.

entries.fullText:
Genesee Grove
very hot weather
Joshua took me
to ride. Aunt [Evelyn?]
took tea with me at
Cousin Davids.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time in Genesee Grove with Joshua and Aunt [Evelyn?]. She also has tea with Cousin David.

entries.fullText:
At Uncle John
Anthony's, Genesee grove
Whiteside Co., Il.
Took tea at Cousin
Charlie's [Davids] - is
a real & radical thinker
on all questions of
the day.
entries.summaryText: Took tea at Cousin Charlie's [Davids] - is a real & radical thinker on all questions of the day.

entries.fullText:
At Uncle John's
day very hot -
Cousin Charlie
wife took tea at
Uncle Johns
all went to union
school house to meeting -
house packed
A year ago this day
Ellen Wright & William Garrison
were married, & I
there at Auburn - and
not with the dear Ann
Eliza
entries.summaryText: All went to union school house to meeting - house packed. A year ago this day Ellen Wright & William Garrison were married, & I there at Auburn - and not with the dear Ann Eliza.

entries.cityOrState:
Genesee Grove to Sterling &
thence to Chicago.
entries.fullText:
took dinner at Janice Birsdalls
Joshua took me to
Sterling. Uncle John
subscribed for Standard--
seemed well
pleased with my
visit & meeting, as
did aunt & all the
boys-- the boys put
together & paid my
fare from Sterling to Chicago
$4.40. found letter
from Cousin Susan with
one from Aunt M. Hoxie--&
one from mother to Aunt A. E.
Told of death of cousin Joshua
Caldwell--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Genesee Grove to Sterling and then to Chicago. She has dinner at Janice Birsdalls and her fare from Sterling to Chicago is paid by the boys. She receives a letter from Cousin Susan with news of the death of cousin Joshua Caldwell.

entries.fullText:
Melissa washed &
10:30 went with
me to see the Chicago
Board of Trade
rooms--splendid
building--but what
a system of gambling
how can men [run?]
their luck thus--
Ironed in P.M.
went to Mrs. Loomis
to Sewing Womens
meeting. got trunk
checked.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits the Chicago Board of Trade rooms and is appalled by the system of gambling. She attends a Sewing Womens meeting at Mrs. Loomis' and gets her trunk checked.

entries.fullText:
Fought mosquitoes every
minute-- heard clock
strike every hour last
night-- had hard
ride-- stopped at
Frances Titus-- found
Esther Titus & Mr.
and Mrs. R. King--
man of [Cumington?]
was there--
S Jane Hyatt Nichols
called to see me.
in evening Mrs. Titus
called with me me at
Ed. Nichols.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Chicago to Battle Creek, encountering mosquitoes and staying with Frances Titus. She meets with several people, including S Jane Hyatt Nichols and Esther Titus.

entries.fullText:
Esther Titus &
I went schools &
gave notice of meeting
for this eve--
Took dinner with
Sarah Jane--husband
seems all right
two beautiful little
girls-- meeting a
very confused one.
many boys & girls.
young America--then
had hard struggle
to get through with
speech--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attends a meeting with Esther Titus and gives notice of a meeting that evening. She has dinner with Sarah Jane and struggles to give a speech at a confused meeting.

entries.fullText: Mrs. [Isaal?] Mott drove me round to see F. Douglass' old place & Lydia Motts lots - dined at George Hyatts. took train at 12:00 - Found George Ford & wife & Marion-- they knew me, though it is 22 years since we met
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits various locations and people in Battle Creek and Ann Arbor.

entries.fullText: Took cars at 9 A.M. had pleasant ride though long and fatiguing and my cold growing worse - scarcely slept any but night at Mr. Fords, such hard breathing - Arrived at Rochester at 1 o clock night walked up to Univers-- Policemen escorted me -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony travels from Ann Arbor to Rochester and is escorted by policemen upon arrival.

entries.fullText: Visited hard though suffering from summer cold-- Found that Sister Gula had had sad weeks living over the illness & death of her dear Ann Eliza but one short year ago-- The vacant place seems none the less for the lapse of a twelve months or the absence of eight months.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Sister Gula in Rochester and learns about her recent struggles with the death of her friend Ann Eliza.

entries.fullText: All went to Plymouth Church but me. Cold too bad to go.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is unable to attend church due to a bad cold.

entries.fullText: Beautiful weather went to Brackett house to call on Senator Pomeroy of Kansas. he is just married to a Boston lady. found them gone to Elmira Called at Evening Express office. at Dr. Allen's office and met G. M. Clark and B. Fish. all look natural
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Senator Pomeroy of Kansas and his new wife in Brackett house, but finds they have gone to Elmira. She also meets G. M. Clark and B. Fish at Dr. Allen's office.

entries.fullText: Helped Gula can some peaches
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony helps Gula can some peaches.

entries.fullText:
Helped Gula
can Tomatoes.
went to artist
Harris' with Arthur
to see about taking
painting lessons.
Mary Hallowell
and Sarah Millis
called while I was
absent.
Letters came from P. R.
and Merritt. the latter
to the mustered out of her
Nice next week.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony helps Gula can tomatoes, goes to an artist's place with Arthur to see about taking painting lessons, and receives letters from P.R. and Merritt.

entries.fullText:
Very pleasant
Gula and self went
to Mt. Hope. it
is a beautiful place
for the dead.
Cousin Lucien
Squier of Brooklyn
came. burried his
brother Frank in
Mt. Hope this A. M.
Stopped here - No. 7
Tibbie Gifford, niece
Ann Eliza's friend, with her
grandmother of Easton came
this evening.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and Gula visit Mt. Hope, a beautiful place for the dead. Cousin Lucien Squier of Brooklyn visits and buries his brother Frank in Mt. Hope. Tibbie Gifford, niece of Ann Eliza's friend, arrives with her grandmother from Easton.

entries.fullText:
Beautiful day -
all of no. 7 dined
at Hannahs -
Gula took Tibbie &
her Grandma to Mt.
Hope in morning
and Maggie, Tibbie
and Ed Blackford
went to Lower Falls in
afternoon -
Got card of invitation
to Theodore Tilton's tin
wedding party - to take
place Monday eve Oct, 2nd -
Isaac & Amy Post spent
evening with us.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about a beautiful day and the activities of her friends and family. She also mentions receiving an invitation to a wedding party.

entries.fullText:
May went to University
with Tibbie & her
Grandma - all
dined at Gula's -
Cousin Lucien
Squire went to Buffalo
on noon train -
Rained in afternoon -
all visited in mothers room -
Cousin Aaron Vail
took tea & spent evening
and took 9.35 train home
Got letter from
P. P. mailed 28th -
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the activities of her friends and family, including a visit from Cousin Aaron Vail and a letter from P. P.

entries.fullText: Cool and showery. Heard Holland in Athenaeum reading room on the Home. Spent P.M. with [?] Mary Hallowell. attempted to go to funeral of Joseph Frost. rain and immense crowd prevented. 55 carriages went to Mt. Hope. Heard Mr. Barttett at Plymouth in evening. Ann Eliza's friend Tibbie Gifford and her grand mother of Easton visiting at Hannah's and here. Tibbie sat in Ann Eliza's place in church. Mother has swollen face and bad cold.
entries.summaryText: Attended a funeral but was prevented by rain and a crowd. Listened to speakers at Athenaeum and Plymouth. Visited with friends and family, including Tibbie Gifford and her grandmother.

entries.fullText: The Giffords left this morning.
entries.summaryText: The Giffords left in the morning.

entries.fullText:
Quilted [?]
comforter for
Merritt's Mary.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony quilted a comforter for Merritt's Mary.

entries.fullText:
Got letter from
Sister Annie - long
and good - her Father
died of cancer in the
stomach -
