Gula, Mary & I took
tea at Cousin George T.
Anthony's - Mother
not able to go -
Aaron came late -
entries.summaryText: Received a letter from Sister Annie about their father's death from cancer. Had tea with Gula, Mary, and Cousin George T. Anthony, while Mother was unable to attend. Aaron arrived late.

entries.fullText:
Cousin George T. and
Rosa & Georgie took
tea at Sister Hannahs
with all of our
No. 7 family - same
maggie & Thomas [?]
entries.summaryText: Cousin George T., Rosa, Georgie, maggie, and Thomas visited Sister Hannahs.

entries.fullText:
Very Rainy -
Went to Church with
Aaron & Gula - their
minister absent - Mr.
Bartlett -
called at Amy
Posts -
entries.summaryText: Attended church with Aaron and Gula, visited Amy Posts, and their minister was absent.

entries.fullText:
Busy packing to leave
on 8:20 train of tomorrow.
Brother Aaron's Uncle
Henry Perine and wife
of Cayuga Co. and Henry
Billing and wife from Wash
came.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony is busy packing to leave Rochester and mentions the arrival of Brother Aaron's Uncle Henry Perine and wife of Cayuga Co. and Henry Billing and wife from Wash.

entries.fullText:
Dined at Cousin
Malintha Howe's &
left for Auburn
at 3 P.M. on way
freight train.
Found Mrs. Wright
well. Mr. Wright
had a severe attack of Rheumatism
near the heart.
they feel constant
alarm.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony dines at Cousin Malintha Howe's and then leaves for Auburn where she finds Mrs. Wright well but Mr. Wright had a severe attack of Rheumatism near the heart and they feel constant alarm.

entries.fullText: Delightful visit with Mrs. Wright and called her daughter Eliza Wright Osbornes. Mrs. W. would be glad to have Woman's Rights revived but fears it will be impossible. Took train 12 noon. just saw Charles Mills at Syracuse Depot. found all well at Number 7 Sarah cleaning Parlors
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Mrs. Wright and her daughter Eliza Wright Osbornes in Auburn and discusses the revival of Woman's Rights.

entries.fullText: Had pleasant visit with Uncle & Aunt. took train 2 P.M. arrived at Albany at 4 P.M. found Phebe and Margaret well, also Lydia and Jane and then Sister Phebe Willis. P.P. not expected till tomorrow P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits her Uncle and Aunt in Palatine Bridge before taking a train to Albany to visit her family.

entries.fullText:
Albany
Bright & beautiful
L. Mott and self called
on Hon. A. J. Colvin &
talked of work for Woman's
Right to suffrage in N.Y.
Mr. C. recommends immediate
work. separate & apart from
the negro question. Mr.
Bingham is ill.
Get no tidings of my
[shawl?] - P.P. came
at 5 P.M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and L. Mott met with Hon. A. J. Colvin to discuss work for Woman's Right to suffrage in N.Y. Mr. C. recommends immediate work. separate & apart from the negro question.

entries.fullText:
Albany
P.P. spent Thursday
night at Ghent. report
Lizzie - all right.
McDaniels at Lydia's
Tea at P.H. Jones
all went to Troy
to hear Senator Wilson
of Mass-- he
made a pitiable
speech-- never said
negro suffrage.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony and others went to Troy to hear Senator Wilson of Mass, who made a pitiable speech and never mentioned negro suffrage.

entries.fullText: Very rainy. P.M. and Margaret dined with us at Lydia's. Called on Mrs. Taff. she is almost gone with consumption. Took tea at Phebe's. and Troy [last?] Hendrick Hudson at 6 P.M. had splendid talk with P.P. until ten.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony dined with Margaret and Lydia, visited a sick friend, and had a conversation with P.P. in Albany.

entries.fullText: Found Mrs Stanton at 464 West 34th st. well and had a cordial welcome from the entire household. had an all days chat. in P.M. Mrs Wilkerson called. in eve, we attended Dr. Loziers opening medical lecture. then called at Dr. Hudsons. found P.P. and all out. at opera.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony had a conversation with Mrs. Stanton, attended a medical lecture, and went to the opera in New York.

entries.fullText:
Went to A.J. office
found new publisher
Mr. Glavis there.
P.P. and Mrs. Dr.
Church came--after
seeing Ps brother Gilbert
and wife on board
Steamer for South
Carolina. We
visited the Californian ship "Young
America"-- Wrote letters
to Phillips & Emil Pretorius
--called at H.B. Blackwell
offices. rode up in
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits A.J. office and finds a new publisher. She also visits the Californian ship Young America and writes letters to Phillips and Emil Pretorius.

entries.fullText:
10th Av. cars. found
memorandum book
not in pocket-- went back
to Dr. Hudsons. P.P.
had not seen it on
floor at office. went
back to Stantons-- fully
sure it was lost with
$110. R.R. passes and
all the years notes--
was not a little chagrinned
at the look
& feeling that somebody had
put his hand in my pocket.
---------------
Mr. P. found the book
at office-- & great joy to me.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony loses her memorandum book with important notes and money, but it is later found by Mr. P. at the office.

entries.fullText: spent last night at Geo. Caldwell's. they are greatly [?] in the death of their Joshua. Eclipse of the sun. pleasant. lunched with Mrs Stanton and Mrs. Greenough - formerly teacher of Rochester called. favors our move for Woman's Rights to suffrage. Mr. Smalley struck from P.P.s article an entire sentence. wholly unauthorized.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the night at Geo. Caldwell's and had lunch with Mrs. Stanton and Mrs. Greenough. Mr. Smalley struck a sentence from P.P.'s article without authorization.

entries.fullText: Mary Caldwell Warren came to Stanton's. I took her to Dr. Lozier. The examined found an ulcer. Man Doctor experimented on her for six years. Then Mary lunched with us at Stanton's.
entries.summaryText: Mary Caldwell Warren visited Stanton's and was taken to Dr. Lozier where an ulcer was found. Mary then had lunch with Susan B. Anthony and Stanton.

entries.fullText:
Wrote of at Mrs
Stantons
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about something at Mrs. Stantons on October 21, 1865.

entries.fullText:
Wrote on the
appeal to Women
of the State for
Constitutional Amendt
to give women the
right of suffrage.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote about writing an appeal to women for constitutional amendment to give women the right of suffrage at Mrs. Stantons on October 22, 1865.

entries.fullText:
at Mrs. Stantons
all day - at Eve,
went to Cooper Institute
to hear Wendell
Phillips - fine audience
and splendid speech -
title "South Victorious"
Saw Dale Owen, Mathie
Griffith & Mrs. Gilbert
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at Mrs. Stanton's and attends a speech by Wendell Phillips at Cooper Institute.

entries.fullText:
Mrs. Stanton went
with me to A.S. Office.
Phillips not there - Then
we called on Tilton -
he read his Editorial
on Seward & Beecher
it is most splendid.
Mrs. went home. I
back to A.S. Office.
Phillips there - he plainly
told Glavis that Pillsbury
was the lead there -
Pillsbury & self left
for Philadelphia at 1.
J. W. Hurn met me
at depot-
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits the A.S. Office with Mrs. Stanton and later meets with Wendell Phillips and others before leaving for Philadelphia with Pillsbury.

entries.fullText:
Annual A.S. Meeting
The Hurns went out
with me - Phillips &
Pillsbury the main
speakers - all
stopped at Joseph
[wharps?] - most
excellent meetings -
Mr. Phillips outdid
himself in the evening
hard rain in evening
still a packed house
entries.summaryText: Susan attended the Annual A.S. Meeting in Westchester with The Hurns, Phillips, and Pillsbury as the main speakers. They stopped at Joseph [wharps?]. Mr. Phillips outdid himself in the evening and it was still a packed house despite the hard rain.

entries.fullText:
Returned to Phil.
Pillsbury to N.Y.
Phillips, Mary Greene and
self sat for group
picture at Hurns.
[Also?]I sat
alone - pretty fair
success--
Remained with
Sarah quiet all
the P.M. on account
of sore, [?] joint
the right one -
entries.summaryText: Susan returned to Phil. and Pillsbury went to N.Y. She sat for a group picture with Phillips and Mary Greene at Hurns. She also sat alone and it was pretty fair success. She remained with Sarah all afternoon due to a sore joint on her right one.

entries.fullText:
J.W. and Sarah
Hurn went with
me to hear W.H.
Furness - beautiful
sermon. Then called
at Anna E. Dickinson's
home 1710 Locust St.
found her - She came
for me after dinner
and drove round to
Fairmount Park - had
two hours delightful
chat with her.
Believe she is true
at heart.
entries.summaryText: Attended a sermon with J.W. and Sarah Hurn, visited Anna E. Dickinson's home, and had a delightful chat with her at Fairmount Park.

entries.fullText:
Spent morning with
Sarah Hurn -
Dined at Edward
Hoppers 829 Chestnut
M-. son of Isaac
L. Hopper the wife [?]
of Lucretia Mott -
at four P.M. went
with J. & S to their
country house.
entries.summaryText: Spent the morning with Sarah Hurn, dined at Edward Hopper's home, and went to J. and S's country house in the afternoon.

entries.fullText:
At James and Lucretia
Mott’s. At the seaside
Home seven miles out
Philadelphia.
Steady rain all day.
James went to German
Town, four miles for
Mary Grew. Mrs. Anna
Heffer came from city.
Had a most delightful
day around a wood
Fire on the library
Hearth.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends a rainy day at James and Lucretia Mott's seaside home in Philadelphia, with James going to German Town and Mrs. Anna Heffer visiting.

entries.fullText:
Went into Phil. with
The Mott’s and Mary Grew.
Went to friends meeting
With Lucretia. 500
School children present.
Felt the need of some
Interesting discourse to them.
Lunched at Saloon
With Lucretia. Then
Took Camden and Amboy
Route to N.Y. The
Moonlight on the bay
Was splendid. Found
All well and Stanton’s.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony goes to a Friends meeting with Lucretia Mott and has lunch with her before traveling to New York via Camden and Amboy, enjoying the moonlight on the bay and finding Stanton's family well.

entries.fullText:
Went to office
Found no letters
from home or other
place.
Spent P.M. in
talk with Mrs. Stanton
At her house
Mr. Pillsbury dined
at Mrs. Stanton’s and
spent eve'g.
His editorial this
week “powerful” Mr.
Stanton says “Are
We Saved” the title.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day with Mrs. Stanton and Mr. Pillsbury at Mrs. Stanton's house.

entries.fullText:
Paid $16. to Miss Thompson
Clerk at A.S. Standard office
Wrote R. W. Mott Chicago
offered her one dollar per
subscriber if she would be
agent for A. S. Standard.
J. W. Harris for pictures
Wrote Mr Irvin
Smith and Mr. W. Reed
of Chicago of the blunder
of their standard address.
Went L. Squier’s. Found
Ellen alone. Lute gone
To St. Louis. Little
Harry not well and
she and Samantha just
returned from West.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony runs errands and writes letters before visiting L. Squier's and finding Ellen alone with her sick child.

entries.fullText:
At Lucien Squier's
34 st. Felix St. Brooklyn
Rained all day.
didn't go out.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at Lucien Squier's house in Brooklyn due to the rain.

entries.fullText:
Went to Beecher's
church with cousin
Samantha [Deal?] Lapham
Dined there
then went to Friends
meeting to hear John
Hunt--then
S. took tea with
me at Nellies--& I
went to Beecher's
again in evening.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony attended church at Beecher's with her cousin Samantha Lapham, then went to a Friends meeting to hear John Hunt. She had tea with S. at Nellies and went to Beecher's again in the evening.

entries.fullText: Went over to A.S. Office - letter from LeMott Mrs. Topp still living - no, letter from home tried to write to Phillips of the [H?] Committee's note - but couldn't succeed
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about going to the A.S. Office, receiving a letter from LeMott, and trying to write to Phillips of the [H?] Committee's note.

entries.fullText: Spent morning in doors and P. M. and evening at Cousin Samantha's - Aunt Iarah Willetts there
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about spending the day indoors and in the evening visiting Cousin Samantha's with Aunt Iarah Willetts.

entries.fullText:
went to A. S. Office
found letter of last
Sunday the 5th from
Mother and Mary, - then
found one in box
that had been there
a week or more -
Things dont go right
at A .S. Office -
Smalley will dictate
out of time & place
After two months
a return. At uncle
Johns Sept 11th the last
this the first break
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony went to the A. S. Office and found letters from her mother and Mary. She also noted that things were not going well at the office.

entries.fullText:
[?] Felix street
spent forenoon
darning stockings and
taking stitches generally
and writing to mother -
Spent P. M. and evening
at A.M. Powells - P.P. there
to tea. ___ got letter
from L. Mott. Mrs Topp
still lives _ taken nothing
but water for ten days
Found Lucien
at home to night.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day darning stockings and writing to her mother. She also visited A.M. Powells and received a letter from L. Mott.

entries.fullText:
Spent day at Theodore
Tiltons - 48 Livingston
Brooklyn - Saw
Augusta Marie there -
she has two brothers
in Leavenworth - our
Doctor.
In Evening P.P.
came with Theodore -
Mrs. Tilton's Step
father is a lawyer
& [genl?] Copperhead
He and Theodore
had a hot discussion
T walked to cars with
me--put me on myrtle ave
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends the day at Theodore Tilton's in Brooklyn, where she sees Augusta Marie and has a discussion with Theodore and his stepfather.

entries.fullText:
Went to A. S. office
P.P. walked with me
to A. J. Davis Canal
St. - Saw Mrs. D.
she seems earnest
& glad to have the
work for women done
but can do very little--
then called Mrs E. L
Rose - she is bright
as ever & wide awake
for W. R. work
Found Mrs. Stanton
preparing for [50th?] birth
party. Went back.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits the A. S. office and meets with Mrs. D. and Mrs. E. L Rose, who are supportive of women's rights work. She also sees Mrs. Stanton preparing for a birthday party.

entries.fullText:
To Dr Hudsons 827
West 22nd St. - Spent
eve and wrote letters
to A.R . Foster on
needs of Standard office -
Listened to O. B.
Frothingham, on
"Justice the mother
of Wisdom"- Dined
at Mrs. Bayards -
went to Theo. Tiltons
Mrs. T. went with
Mrs. S. to see Mrs
C Bowen
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent the day at various locations, listened to a lecture by O.B. Frothingham, dined at Mrs. Bayards, and visited Mrs. C Bowen with Mrs. T.

entries.fullText:
Copied from Mr
Frothingham's Sermon
- went to A. S
Office - P.P bluer
than ever with
the unsettled state
of affairs - at
4 went to Flushing
to Marian Luther
[Walther?]-- has
aunt Lucy Allen
been sick there
for a month
James miserable
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony copied a sermon, went to the A.S. Office, and visited Marian Luther in Flushing where she learned that Lucy Allen had been sick for a month and James was miserable.

entries.fullText:
Yesterday & to day
splendid Indian
summer days —
with more lame
heels & the joints
and thin shoes
for three weeks
have a severe cold
— just two months
since I took that
terrible one in Chicago
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the weather and her health, mentioning a severe cold she caught in Chicago two months prior.

entries.fullText:
Splendid & warm
Mr. walker too
ill to go to N. York—
Put new glass
buttons on cloak -
this is its 3rd winter—
felt for. N.Y. at 1 P. M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about the weather and her friend Mr. Walker being too ill to go to New York. She also mentions putting new buttons on her cloak and heading to New York at 1 PM.

entries.fullText: Meeting at 11 A.M. in the Friends Meeting House - excellent- P.P. Spoke well - Dined at Isaac Hallecks- visited grave of Eliza W. Farnham
entries.summaryText: Attended a meeting at Friends Meeting House, had lunch at Isaac Hallecks, and visited the grave of Eliza W. Farnham.

entries.fullText: Returned to N.Y. in A. M.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony returned to New York on November 20, 1865.

entries.fullText: at Mrs Stantons rained all the day long
entries.summaryText: On November 21, 1865, Susan B. Anthony spent the day at Mrs. Stanton's despite the rain.

entries.fullText: Called at Dr Taylors -- Cousin Lizzie [?] & Jeff went to Brooklyn to spend day with Samantha [?]
entries.summaryText: Called at Dr Taylors and went to Brooklyn to spend the day with Cousin Lizzie, Jeff, and Samantha.

entries.fullText: At Cousin Samantha's after dinner went to A. S. office-- thence to J. Hudsons found Phebe Jones & LeMott there-- went to Dr. Gleevers Memorial meeting then left at P.M.
entries.summaryText: Visited Cousin Samantha's, went to A. S. office and J. Hudsons, attended Dr. Gleevers Memorial meeting, and left in the afternoon.

entries.fullText:
Lydia, Phebe & self
Took 3 P.M. dinner
at A.M. Powells.
Then staid all
night at cousin
Samanthas [?]
entries.summaryText: Had dinner at A.M. Powells and stayed overnight at cousin Samanthas.

entries.fullText:
Spent Forenoon
with cousin
Samantha. and
after dinner. all
with P.P. went
to [?] N. Jersy
to visit Lucy Stone
Cousin S.
seemed to enjoy
their talk
entries.summaryText: Visited Lucy Stone in N. Jersy with cousin Samantha and P.P.

entries.fullText:
At Lucy Stone's
at Roseville-
Phebe Jones, Sylvia
Mott, Parker Pillsby
and myself - very pleasant day
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends a pleasant day at Lucy Stone's in Roseville with Phebe Jones, Sylvia Mott, and Parker Pillsby.

entries.fullText:
Lydia, Phebe and
P.P. went into N.Y.
with Mr P.
Lucy & I visited
Le told me that others
S. last summer gave
her [?] experience
Samantha called
in P.M.
Every body who has
husband, home &
children to look
after has enough
without public work
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends time with Lydia, Phebe, P.P., Mr P., Lucy, Le, and Samantha. Le shares an experience from last summer. Susan reflects on the challenges of balancing public work with family responsibilities.

entries.fullText:
Decided not to go
M. A. McLean Pitcher's.
Lucy went into
NY with me.
Called at A. S. office
- at Antoniette's and
lunched at Mrs.
Stanton's - Nellie Eaton
also.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony decided not to go to M. A. McLean Pitcher's and instead went to NY with Lucy. She called at A. S. office, Antoniette's and lunched at Mrs. Stanton's with Nellie Eaton.

entries.fullText:
Called at Dr.
Cheever's - dined
at Mathe Griffiths
Dale Owen not in
Mathe bright and
true as ever
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony called at Dr. Cheever's and dined at Mathe Griffiths. Dale Owen was not there but Mathe was bright and true as ever.

entries.fullText: The Evening Post refused to print Mrs. Stanton's word of Robert Dale Owen's letter for Constitutional Amendment. [Jack?] it Tribune. Giving not in. Dined at Dr. Cheever's. Also P.P. there went to meeting the Doctor's Memorial to Congress in capital.
entries.summaryText: Mrs. Stanton's letter was refused to be printed, had dinner at Dr. Cheever's and attended a meeting for the Doctor's Memorial to Congress.

entries.fullText: Decided to go to Worcester to see A.R. Foster. on A.S. and W.R. business. called at Dr. Cheever's Dr. Hudson & A.S. office--found P.P. out. Back to lunch at Mrs. Stanton's. P.P. did not come to [?] the Norwich Line-- the N.Y. City Steamer Found Hannah Thurt & her mother on board--
entries.summaryText: Visited Worcester for business, had lunch at Mrs. Stanton's and encountered Hannah Thurt and her mother on the N.Y. City Steamer.

entries.fullText:
My Mother's 72d
birth day. Sixth
Anniversary of John
Brown's execution.
Stopped at J.A. Newlands.
learned A.R.
and I. S. Foster were
gone from home.
went on to Boston
in P.M. and to
S.J. Nowells, [corner?]
of Williams St. Cambridge
not his Newton bus--
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony writes about her mother's birthday, John Brown's execution anniversary, and her travels to Boston and Cambridge.

entries.fullText:
Boston
called at Dr.
H.K. Hunts--
found her ready for
a W.R. work.
Found Dr. Zackshefskah
gone. took
dinner at Mr. Garrison's.
Poor Mrs. G. has
never fully recovered
her shock of two years ago.
Giles & Kate Stebbins
there. Fannie and [Nellie?]
going on to Philadelphia
to Wendell's wedding
on the 6th.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony visits Dr. H.K. Hunts and Mr. Garrison in Boston and learns about the upcoming wedding of Wendell. She also meets with friends and acquaintances.

entries.fullText:
Called at A.S.
office. Saw Whipple
May, and Walcutt
then went Wendall
Phillips house--
found him-- he
consented to use
$500. W.R. fund--
Talked of M.P.P
and Mr. S. not
fully harmonizing
in the A.S. office
at New York.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony called at A.S. office, saw Whipple May, and Walcutt, then went Wendall Phillips house. Talked of M.P.P and Mr. S. not fully harmonizing in the A.S. office at New York.

entries.fullText:
Called on Dr.
Hunt-- then
on Mrs. Dall--
Then attended Ex.
Com. meeting on
the Glavis scheme.
evidently a good
deal of misunderstanding
as to real facts
--undue weight given
to all on Smalley's statements
--went back
to Mrs. Nowells then
to Mrs. Severances.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony called on Dr. Hunt, then on Mrs. Dall. Then attended Ex. Com. meeting on the Glavis scheme. Evidently a good deal of misunderstanding as to real facts.

entries.fullText:
delightful day
with Mrs. Severance. She is
earnest for work
for women.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends a delightful day with Mrs. Severance and discusses work for women.

entries.fullText:
National Thanksgiving Day
at Mrs. C.M. Severance's
West Newton. Mass.
The daughter Julia went
into Boston with her affirmed
the three sons. Seymour
Sibley and Pierre at home
Snow fell all day.
had pleasant visit
with Mrs. Severance.
read Buskin's letter
on woman. also some
in Mrs. E.W. Farmham's
woman and her era.
W. R. takes something
the same now of Mrs. F.
the superiority or total
unlikeness of the sexes.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends Thanksgiving Day at Mrs. C.M. Severance's in West Newton, Massachusetts. She reads letters and books on women's issues and discusses the superiority or total unlikeness of the sexes with W. R.

entries.fullText:
Cold and Clear.
Took sleigh ride to
depot at 10 O'Clock A.M.
Stopped at [Natuk?] took
the 2:30 train to see
Mrs. E.F. Lockwood
a young widow of 20 years
whom Phillips and Pillsbury
have taken under their
wings. She is bright
and beautiful and gives
promise. She will try her
oratorical wings with me
so soon as I can go into
the field. Got to the
Fosters at dusk.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony takes a sleigh ride to the depot and visits Mrs. E.F. Lockwood, a young widow whom Phillips and Pillsbury have taken under their wings. They discuss oratorical opportunities and Anthony arrives at the Fosters at dusk.

entries.fullText:
bright and cold again
the day passed and no
chance for talk. Abby
busy about house and
Stephen gone to the city
all day.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spends a bright and cold day with Abby, who is busy about the house, and Stephen, who is gone to the city all day. No chance for talk.

entries.fullText:
Returned to New
York - and commenced
W. R. work
in earnest.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony returned to New York and started working on W. R. in earnest.

entries.fullText:
Writing and
folding and
addressing
petitions
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony wrote, folded, and addressed petitions.

entries.fullText:
Christmas
Mrs. S. and I
wrote all the A.M.
at 2 P.M. I went
to Brooklyn. found
cousins Geo & Aaron
Vail there. Oliver
[?] married.
and a general jolly
time there was at
Lucien Squier's.
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony spent Christmas writing in the morning and then went to Brooklyn to visit family and friends, including cousins Geo and Aaron Vail, and attended a jolly time at Lucien Squier's.

entries.fullText:
Called on
Beecher. Too
late. must
get there before
9 A.M.
Ex. Com. Meeting
in Boston. Pillsbury
and Powell there
entries.summaryText: Susan B. Anthony called on Beecher in Boston and was too late. She attended an Executive Committee meeting with Pillsbury and Powell.

entries.fullText:
[Called on
Beecher - but
was too late]
Theodore Wilton
called at A. S.
Office. Talked of
of an "Equal rights"
Committee or society.
and the "National Standard"
its organ.

entries.fullText:
Antidote for Poison.-Dr. J. Edmonds, a
prominent London physician writes as follows
to the London Times:

"I enclose a simple, safe and accessible pre-
scription for the whole range of acid corrosive
poisons, which if promptly used, will almost
invariably save live. Mix two ounces of pow-
der chalk or magnesia, or one ounce of washing
soda, with a pint of milk, and swallow it at one
draught; then tickle the back of the throat with
a feather or finger, so as to produce vomiting.
Afterwards drink freely of milk and water, and
repeat the vomiting so as to thoroughly wash
out the stomach. Any quantity of chalk or
magnesia may be taken with safety, but soda in
large quantities is injurious. I may add that the
narcotics are excepted. Milk is an antidote for
almost all the poisons, and especially if followed
by vomiting."
-Cut this out for preservation.
entries.summaryText: Dr. J. Edmonds, a prominent London physician, shares a simple and safe prescription for the whole range of acid corrosive poisons in a letter to the London Times.
